prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded. 
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor 
 Ddeath by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June. 
 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen. 
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The special exhibit in the House of Horrors is based on a rumour that shocked society in London.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 1
Testimony: An impression of the visage was taken directly from the corpse...in accordance with Tusspells family principles.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 2
Testimony: I enlisted the aid of the gravedigger, and created a mould for the head in the cemetery just before the interment.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 3
Testimony: I hid myself until he gave me a signal. ...I was there for a very long time that night.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 4
Testimony: It took me a very long time because it was before the onset of rigor mortis.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 5
Testimony: As dawn approached, I was very worried that I could be discovered.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 6
Testimony: I hurried to finish my work in the half hour before sunrise. Then I left as soon as the corpse was interred.
Person: Tusspells

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by carefully reading all the evidence and testimonies provided.

First, looking at the testimonies, they all seem to be from Esmeralda Tusspells, the owner of the Madame Tusspells Museum. Testimony 0 mentions the special exhibit based on a rumor. Testimony 1 talks about taking an impression from the corpse, Testimony 2 involves a gravedigger and a mold made before the interment, Testimony 3 mentions hiding until a signal, Testimony 4 refers to the time before rigor mortis, Testimony 5 discusses the worry about being discovered, and Testimony 6 says the work was finished in half an hour before sunrise and then left after the corpse was interred.

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 15 is the Waxwork Head of the Professor, which was stolen. Evidence 0 is the Armband, which is from Susato. Evidence 1 is the Great Exhibition Newspaper. Evidence 2 is the Experiment Sketch. Evidence 3 is the Mysterious Contraption, a crossbow belonging to Enoch Drebber. Evidence 4 is the Piece of Green Cloth with scorch marks. Evidence 5 is the Photograph of the Victim, showing a stab wound. Evidence 6 is the Autopsy Report stating neck broken and chest stab. Evidence 7 is the Screwdriver named Andrew with blood traces matching the victim's wound. Evidence 8 is the Photograph of the Balloon. Evidence 9 is Drebber's Card with oil. Evidence 10 is the Wooden Birdcage that crashed into the Crystal Tower. Evidence 11 is the Photograph of Drebber with a monocle. Evidence 12 is the Camera from the waxwork, showing dark stains. Evidence 13 is the Broken Glass found on Drebber's clothes. Evidence 14 is the Science Trophy. Evidence 15 is the Waxwork Head. Evidence 16 is the Killer's Autopsy Report, redacted, but mentions death by hanging. Evidence 17 is the Post-Explosion Photograph with blood traces. Evidence 18 is Drebber's Contract. Evidence 19 is the Ten-Year-Old Article about the Professor's supposed resurrection.

Now, focusing on the testimonies, Tusspells created a waxwork head from the corpse. But in the evidence, Evidence 15 is the Waxwork Head that was stolen. So, if Tusspells made the waxwork, that would be her own exhibit, but it was stolen. However, Testimony 0 says the exhibit is based on a rumor, which might not directly contradict, but Testimony 1 mentions taking an impression from the corpse, which aligns with creating a waxwork. 

Wait, but looking deeper, Testimony 2 says she enlisted a gravedigger and made a mold before interment. Testimony 3 mentions hiding until a signal. Testimony 4 refers to before rigor mortis. Testimony 5 talks about being worried about being discovered. Testimony 6 says she finished in half an hour before sunrise and left after the interment.

But looking at Evidence 15, the Waxwork Head was stolen, implying it was made by Tusspells, but if she made it from the corpse, that would require access during the night, which aligns with the testimonies. However, Testimony 6 says she hurried to finish in half an hour before sunrise, which is 30 minutes. But creating a waxwork head from a corpse would likely take longer than that, especially considering the process of making a mold and casting wax. So, the time frame might be a problem. Testimony 6 says she left as soon as the corpse was interred, but if she made the mold before that, the time might be too short.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 16, the Killer's Autopsy Report, which mentions death by hanging, but the victim in the case is Mr. Asman, who was killed in the explosion. So, the autopsy report of the Professor from ten years ago might not directly contradict unless there's a connection. But the testimonies are about the current case, so maybe that's not it.

Wait, perhaps looking at Testimony 3, where she says she hid until a signal, which could mean she was present during the execution. But the Killer's Autopsy Report (Evidence 16) mentions death by hanging, so maybe that's a clue. However, the victim in the current case is Mr. Asman, who was killed in the explosion, not the Professor.

Wait, maybe focusing on the time in Testimony 6, she finished in half an hour before sunrise. That's 30 minutes, which is very quick for making a waxwork. The process of making a mold and casting wax typically takes longer. So, Testimony 6 might be a contradiction because it's too short a time.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 4, she mentions it took a long time because it was before rigor mortis. Rigor mortis typically starts around 3-4 hours after death. So, if she started before rigor mortis, the process would take longer, but Testimony 6 says she finished quickly. That could be a contradiction because if rigor mortis was a factor, she couldn't have finished in 30 minutes.

So, Testimony 6 says she finished in half an hour, but Testimony 4 says it took a long time because before rigor mortis. That's a direct contradiction because if rigor mortis was a factor, it would take longer, not just 30 minutes.

Therefore, Testimony 6 (number 6) contradicts Testimony 4 (number 4).
</think>

Person: Drebber
Testimony 2

Person: Drebber
Testimony 5

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony carefully.

First, looking at the testimonies. Testimony 0 says that the reason Drebber was in Lowgate Cemetery was for moonlighting. Testimony 1 mentions a newspaper article illustrating what he saw that night. Testimony 2 claims he never saw the Professor, though. Testimony 3 says he saw another graverobber. Testimony 4 states there was no gunshot or blood. Testimony 5 mentions a visit from a young woman who made a wax model of him. Testimony 6 says he gave up his dream because of a newspaper article.

Now, looking at the evidence. Evidence 19 is a newspaper article about an eyewitness to the Professor's supposed resurrection. Evidence 15 is the waxwork head stolen from the museum. Evidence 12 is a camera that Drebber used for graverobbing, with staining on the bellows. Evidence 17 shows blood traces after the explosion.

I think the key here is to find a contradiction. Testimony 2 says Drebber never saw the Professor, but Evidence 19 talks about a newspaper article that Drebber saw, which was based on his own actions. Wait, no, Testimony 2 is from Drebber, so he's saying he didn't see the Professor, but the article (Evidence 19) is about someone else's account. Hmm.

Wait, Testimony 2 is Drebber saying he didn't see the Professor, but Evidence 19 is about a newspaper article recounting an eyewitness's tale. Maybe there's a contradiction here because Testimony 2 implies Drebber didn't witness the Professor's return, but the article (Evidence 19) suggests someone did. So, perhaps Testimony 2 and Evidence 19 contradict each other because Drebber claims he didn't see the Professor, but the article says someone did.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 15, the waxwork head was stolen, but Testimony 5 mentions a young woman making a wax model of Drebber. Maybe that's not a contradiction. 

Wait, Testimony 2 is Drebber saying he never saw the Professor, but Evidence 19 is about an article based on an eyewitness account. So, if Drebber didn't see the Professor, but the article says someone did, that's a contradiction. So, the evidence (article) and testimony (Drebber's statement) are conflicting.

So, the pair would be Evidence 19 and Testimony 2. But in the JSON, it's "evidence": 19, "testimony": 2.
</think>

Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15

Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor

 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen.

Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.

Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It all began at the scene when I saw the waxwork and the note tucked inside its jacket.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 1
Testimony: The actual body of the victim, as indicated in the note's instructions, was beneath the experimentation stage.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The body had to be 'arranged' in certain ways to implicate the defendant...which was my job.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 3
Testimony: The actual cause of death was the neck trauma Asman suffered from the thirty-foot fall.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 4
Testimony: I stood over the victim's corpse where it lay in the toppled cage and plunged the screwdriver into the chest.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 5
Testimony: I enlisted the help of the entire Forensic Investigation Team to dress the scene appropriately.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 6
Testimony: The truth about the execution ten years ago is a state secret of the highest level. I had to protect it.
Person: Sithe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony are contradicting each other in this case. I'm a bit new to this, but I'll take it step by step.

First, I'll look at the testimonies given by Courtney Sithe. Testimony 3 says that the actual cause of death was the neck trauma from a thirty-foot fall. Testimony 4 mentions that Sithe himself plunged a screwdriver into the chest of the victim. But wait, the autopsy report (Evidence 6) states that the victim was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object, and the screwdriver (Evidence 7) has traces of blood matching the victim's wound. So, if Sithe used the screwdriver to stab the victim, that would align with the autopsy and the screwdriver's evidence. However, Testimony 4 says he did that, but Testimony 3 says the cause of death was the fall, not the stab wound. That seems contradictory because the fall caused the neck trauma, but the stab wound would have been the actual cause of death.

Wait, but the autopsy report says the victim was stabbed in the chest, which would be the cause of death, not the fall. So, Testimony 3 is incorrect because it claims the cause of death was the fall, but the autopsy says the stab wound was the cause. Therefore, Testimony 3 contradicts the autopsy report (Evidence 6). However, Testimony 4 aligns with Evidence 7, so that's not the contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe I'm mixing up the causes. The fall caused the neck trauma, which might have killed him instantly, but the stab wound is mentioned as the cause of death in the autopsy. So, the fall might have been the immediate cause, but the stab wound is also a factor. This is a bit confusing. I think the main contradiction is between Testimony 3 stating the cause of death was the fall and the autopsy report stating the stab wound was the cause. Therefore, Testimony 3 contradicts Evidence 6.
</think>
